comments.commentBody: There are any number of groups of Americans  who represent less than 1% of the population. That is not a legitimate reason to dismiss out of hand their quest to have their full humanity recognized.

The Chairman of The Board for Texas Health (a large group of hospitals & clinics in TX) is a career insurance & private wealth man. His company bought life insurance policies from the living and cashes in when the person dies.
Think his greatest concern is patient care or bottom line?

I'm not going into the math, but I doubt that you could do this with fewer than 25 to 40 staff.  In particular, 12 hour nursing shifts would be impossible. A case can be made for or against haz--mat type suits. I do think that it would be challenging for almost anyone to avoid contamination.  This thread seems to be very inviting to the naive and the uncharitable, most of whom probably could not do this work for an hour.

While I agree with your first point, hundreds of health care workers have died from Ebola in West Africa. Up to and including Sierra Leone's equivalent of a Surgeon General.

The incompetence of our medical industry is, again, stunning but not surprising if you've been in an American hospital lately, but West Africa has not been very successful protecting their workers either.

I have not read all 1700 comments so apologies in advance if someone had already pointed this out:

CDC as well as administrators from Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital Dallas needs to come to terms with their hubris and unpreparedness rather than quick to blame the nurses who work at the front line. It is quite telling that doctors and nurses from Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), working in a far from state of the art makeshift field hospitals in West Africa and dealing with hundreds of patients for the last few months, hardly ever get themselves infected, whereas here in the US, a single patient leads to two hospital worker infections with perhaps more to come. I find this lack of preparedness and arrogance far more alarming than the disease itself.

Firstly, it takes nowhere near years to master sterile technique  - hours will do - (something's not right with those students!)  and there is no need for sterile technique, only clean. Removing the equipment is very difficult, though, and would require help. And the hospital should have provided better equipment for the staff - we don't go to work to give our actual lives for our patients. We've been discussing this at my hospital, naturally, and we don't currently have access to appropriate protective clothing, so I'd have to assume very few others do either, but if Hazmat teams have it, hospitals could get it, too.

Why is the argument of banning flights presented in an all or nothing way? We could set up special flight circumstances for healthcare workers, medical supplies, experts, etc. But, why are we allowing general tourist travel in and out of the hot zones? The latter is not taking the seriousness of this disease along with its relatively easy spread to health care workers into account.

Whether a traveler comes from Liberia or Madrid, US customs will still know the person's travel origin.

Ron, where have you been?

There is a travel ban in place silly!
It's just a travel ban on Americans who have been exposed to Ebola may now not fly.

Of course, there is still no travel ban on the 150 people who fly into our country every day from West Africa.
That would be silly.

One ebola patient lies his way into the USA, and now we have two healthcare workers already infected and hundreds more possibly infected people (healthcare workers, airline passengers) we need to track.  Meanwhile, the administration sits on its hands as non-essential travel continues between West Africa and the USA.  Obama's promise of more "aggressive monitoring" is not reassuring.  I've never been so disappointed in him.  Can I get a refund on my 2012 vote and contributions?

Agreed. That's what we get when we accept a fractionalized, more or less for profit healthcare system that is reactive (to liability). Everyone refuses a universal, i.e. public, healthcare system until our current system breaks down. The fact that a patient from Liberia who told healthcare workers that he was in contact with Ebola patients  was discharged from a hospital ER is inexcusable. Now, we need a Federal government response? No, we have needed a Federal government response. Obamacare is better than nothing but it not enough. It will undoubtedly be difficult to rid the US of a multi-trillion dollar industry, i.e. healthcare, that is immune to foreign competition that employs so many American and makes so many so rich. But, as we quarrel over quarantines and lawsuits mount while big pharma contemplates the profitability of a vaccine and how much it will cost us (US), nature will take its course. Forget terrorism. We perhaps and the US's protection of the $ are our worst enemy.

Why is there any reason to believe that the federal government, that doesn't run any actual health care system, is better suited to oversee the treatment of patients than any of the great healthcare facilities in the country.
Meanwhile there are the top hospitals who have long perfected their protocols and have teams that are very experienced at treating the most infectious diseases that are allot more suited to the task. The reason that all went well at Emory and Texas already has two infections and are bracing for more, is because Emory had one of the top systems in the country for these types of diseases and in Texas they were making basic mistakes from the start.
Even now that the CDC discovered that they were not at all up to the task, they still insist that for some reason they should be left in charge because after all they are working on figuring it out.
The department in the federal government are made up of people, and there is no reason to believe that just because a person is employed by the government that he is any better than other professionals who have the same qualifications and allot more experience.
This is the umpteenth time that we have seen that the people that work for the federal government are less competent than those who work for organizations where people are personally responsible for the end results and they answer to people who truly care, and not just because the government pays them to do so.

The CDC, and all officials, seem more motivated to prevent panic in the public, than they are to actually taking tough, decisive action.  They could do both by banning incoming travelers from West Africa.  The excuse "how will health workers mobilize?" rings false.  Charter flights?  Military flights?  And if it's harm to economic activity they are actually worried about, they have it completely backward:  fear will harm the economy more than banning those insignificant numbers of potentially explosive travelers.  The call to ban travel is a huge chorus, a roar really, on medical news sites, coming from medical professionals.   It's astonishing and ironic that we may ban some travel within the U.S. before we ban it from the epicenter.  You couldn't make this up.  The more they tell us not to worry, the more worried I get, because the mistakes are egregious.
An even more practical and economic approach would be a targeted, evidence- based travel ban for 3-6 months.  America will live without visitors from Liberia for 6 months.
I know recently graduated nurses who would agree with you. But no one wants to pay for it.

Could not agree with you more.  I have been in hospitals in MA and RI the past 10 years and found almost no nursing staff under the age of 40 who  were competent or clean. Unless you are hospitalized, you may think nursing is the same as 20 years ago. It is not.

I know I will be criticized for my statement: The US has poor training for Nursing. Kent State should be investigated and put on probation. Training, training, and more training needed, especially in infectious diseases. Sorry, but that's my opinion, based on years of my study.   Dr. Arnold Schwartz.   PS: The average hospital patient seldom sees an R.N., but one of the many sub-nursing people. The situation is awful.

Government makes mistakes, therefore it must be caused by excessive size? So smaller, less well-funded government would somehow have more resources to fight disease? The mental gymnastics of Republican apologists are amazing!
Because we don't have a surgeon general. A candidate  for the position has been blocked by the Republicans.

Maybe we'd have a surgeon general if we didn't have an ax-grinding ideologue in the White House who insisted on injecting gun control into an unrelated position. But, hey, liberals, if that means that your guy ignored ebola, I'm sure the righteous satisfaction makes it all worthwhile.

Chris Matthews (MSNBC) asked this question of his guest, Dr. Anthony Fauci. Dr. Fauci said the absence a Surgeon General was of no consequence in this Ebola outbreak. The results would be no different.

I'm sure Chris will ask this another 10 or 20 times.
Regarding the unfolding Ebola crisis, why are we hearing from the CDC instead of the country's top public health officer, the US Surgeon General?

its time to stop the self monitoring of doctors and nurses and require all who treat an Ebola patient be quarantined, get the cops to guard their residences if you have to.. We can't trust these people, just look at what happened by trusting the "self- monitoring" system in place, one nurse cheated, just like the NBC news crew.. enough is enough.. prosecute them if they violate mandatory quarantine.. we do it for TB patients who violate their treatment protocols and we should do it with Ebola.

Simple--there is no cure because in a capitalist medical system there is no profit motive to cure a relatively rare disease. Public health? Life and death? These forces do not affect the invisible hand of the market.

respectfully disagree
given overall lack of exposure and well developed infection control professional community - the hospital didn't have the right equipment, as laurie garrett said we had the hubris that we could handle this a la john wayne and the random nature of quarantine for family members and observation for others - the only mistake as far as I can tell is we assumed that family members were less protected and hospital caregivers could go on their merry way - two infected nurses (praying for them) and lots of others worried as a result - but no one in the family contacts has gotten sick...seems to belie PSST comment
in the decentralized health care system we have and limited funds for public health i think cdc has done as much as they can do - articulate standards and hold the INDUSTRY accountable for following them - all argues in favor of designating special treatment units which after a short week of crisis management has been done

I think a lot of the deficiency of the protocol can be traced to Western hubris.  Sure, the ebola bacteria can kills Africans by the score, but it would never dare to attack middle class white Americans in the same way!  The might have to wear level 4 containment garments in Africa but here we will just give them rubber gloves and googles.
WHO guidelines for ebola care in West Africa recommend disinfecting thermometers and stethoscopes with 70% isopropyl alcohol.

A local politician in the Dallas area says that hand sanitizer has sold out citywide. Has it even been determined if alcohol has any affect on Ebola?
Some viruses aren't affected by isopropanol or ethanol, like picornaviruses.
Our federal vs state power is a problem for our CDC to be effective.
Because not every nurse (or doctor) is an expert on infectious diseases and Ebola in particular?
Those health care workers won't stay on the job for long if they don't come up with safer and better ways to care for Ebola patients.

Like Spain was prepared? And Germany? Please, face reality, no one is perfect and some things we have to learn as we go along. And, yes, people will die.  We're no better or wiser or more equipped than our ancestors who had to suffer through bubonic plague, Spanish flu, small pox, etc.
Right now, I am far more concerned about hysteria than about Ebola.
Right now I'm much more concerned about the CDCs leadership than I am about an ebola epidemic in the United States.
You're saying there is under 50% compliance with proper hand washing procedures at a leading hospital and this is supposed to make us feel better?

I work in a leading hospital in New Jersey. Basic hand washing and gloving techniques have been strictly enforced for the past 2 years (as most hospitals across the country).  At last count we are under 50% compliance. Healthcare workers need to be more cautious and careful with overall prevention and compliance of precautions. The CDC is not the only medical organization who are trying to calm the hysteria of ebola. Most infectious disease experts across the world agree that this disease is not easily transmissible with proper safeguards especially in developed countries. We should listen more to medical experts and learn from the mistakes made and not those who are more interested in TV ratings or mid-term elections.
